block.p: U.S. Ambassador to Kenya Had Sought Safer Building The American Ambassador to Kenya and the Defense Department were so alarmed about threats to the embassy in Kenya that they had requested a safer building, but were rejected for budgetary reasons, the State Department said. Senior State Department officials said they did not believe that Ambassador Prudence Bushnell had cited any particular terrorist threat in her two requests for a new embassy building.

U.S. Ambassador to Kenya Had Sought Safer Building The American Ambassador to Kenya and the Defense Department were so alarmed about threats to the embassy in Kenya that they had requested a safer building, but were rejected for budgetary reasons, the State Department said. Senior State Department officials said they did not believe that Ambassador Prudence Bushnell had cited any particular terrorist threat in her two requests for a new embassy building.

Ambassador Bushnell went on Kenyan television to address accusations that Americans were more concerned about protecting their own people and guarding their embassy than helping Kenyans killed or hurt in the bombings.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright was preparing to fly home from Germany today with the bodies of 10 of the 12 Americans killed in the Nairobi bombing.

Iraq Halting Arms Monitoring Iraq is freezing all current United Nations weapons inspections as well as threatening the long-term monitoring that is crucial to preventing the country from producing weapons of mass destruction in the future, United Nations officials said.

The United Nations' chief weapons inspector, Richard Butler, said a tense standoff between Mr. Butler and Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister, Tariq Aziz -- depicted in video footage that has been shown around the world -- never happened.

Swiss Banks Settle Claims Representatives of Swiss banks and Holocaust victims said in New York that they had settled a class-action lawsuit under which two major Swiss banks are to pay $1.25 billion to tens of thousands of victims of the Nazi era and their heirs.

Findings in Nigerian's Autopsy The jailed Nigerian opposition leader, Moshood Abiola, died of natural causes, according to international experts who issued their final autopsy findings. The Chief Coroner of Ontario said Mr. Abiola, 60, had suffered from a narrowing of the arteries and an enlarged heart.

Indonesian Officers Sentenced Two military officers whose troops killed four university students in May, setting off a cataclysm of violence and the resignation of President Suharto, were sentenced to less than a year in prison. A military tribunal found the officers guilty of violating military orders and of not controlling their troops.

Burmese Dissident's Protest Daw Aung San Suu Kyi loaded up a van with food, water and other supplies and embarked again on one of the few means of protest she has: driving into the Burmese countryside as far as she can until the military authorities who rule Myanmar stop her. Separately, the authorities said they had still not decided whether to try or expel 18 foreign pro-democracy advocates who were arrested on Sunday in downtown Yangon, the former Rangoon.

Clinton Defense Fund Surpasses $2 Million President Clinton's new legal defense fund has raised in excess of $2 million in six months, aided by a campaign that partly blamed the Whitewater independent counsel for the First Couple's financial plight, said several supporters briefed in recent days on the fund's progress.

On the President's Testimony President Clinton will answer every question put to him when he testifies on Monday in the grand jury investigation into his relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky, a White House spokesman indicated.

Victory for a New Republican Senator Ben Nighthorse Campbell of Colorado, left, who easily defeated a conservative challenger Tuesday night in his first election since leaving the Democratic Party, called his victory a triumph for Republican moderates. His Democratic opponent will be Dottie Lamm, a women's rights advocate and the wife of former Gov. Richard Lamm. In the gubernatorial primary, the Democrats chose Gail Schoettler, the lieutenant governor, to face Bill Owens, the state treasurer, a Republican.

Suspect's Family Subpoenaed Relatives of Russell Eugene Weston Jr., the man accused of killing two police officers in the United States Capitol last month, were served grand jury subpoenas during their first visit to Mr. Weston since the shootings, their lawyers said.

Columnist's Reprieve Criticized The Boston Globe's decision to suspend rather than dismiss the columnist Mike Barnicle drew criticism from inside and outside the newsroom, including accusations that he had benefited from a racial double standard.

New Look at Global Warming Scientists report in the journal Nature that a new analysis of data from satellites -- one that incorporates the decaying of the satellites' orbits -- shows that the atmosphere has become warmer, but not as much as the surface has. They report an atmospheric warming of about 0.13 of a degree Fahrenheit per decade.

Spy Satellite Is Destroyed An Air Force Titan 4A rocket carrying a spy satellite blew up shortly after its launching from Cape Canaveral, Fla., creating a $1 billion Roman candle and dealing a setback to the space-reconnaissance program.
Temblor Jolts California An earthquake registering 5.4 on the Richter scale of ground motion shook parts of Northern California, rattling more nerves than buildings. No injuries were reported.

Ramsey Case to Grand Jury The District Attorney in Boulder County, Colo., said he would take the JonBenet Ramsey murder case to a grand jury to help develop evidence in the unsolved slaying. The announcement came after Gov. Roy Romer said he would not appoint a special prosecutor in the case.

Two Democrats Clash As a Third Mainly Watches Mark Green and Charles E. Schumer argued over Social Security and the tone of the Senate primary campaign, while the third major Democrat in the race, Geraldine A. Ferraro, mostly sat by silently in the candidates' second debate.

Dispute Over CUNY Plan The City University of New York and the New York State Department of Education are battling over whether CUNY needs Board of Regents approval to enact a far-reaching plan to bar students needing remedial help from its 11 senior colleges.

Suspected Nazi States His Case A 79-year-old former potato chip salesman and restaurateur, Jack Reimer, took the witness stand to defend himself against charges that during World War II he was a commander in the Trawniki camp, helped the Nazis liquidate Jewish ghettos in Poland and assisted in mass executions of Jews.

Nude Exhibition Finds a Venue The Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn., will present a variation of an exhibition on the nude in 20th-century art that was canceled last month by the Whitney Museum of American Art. The show, which is to open next June, will include an installation by the performance artist Karen Finley, a drawing class in which she and others will take part as nude models.
A Bid for the Competition Mentor Graphics made an unsolicited tender offer for Quickturn Design Systems, a rival in systems that automate chip design. The companies are in patent litigation.

Findings at Livent The new management of Livent has determined that the impresario who helped start the concern kept two sets of books to conceal extravagant spending, according to two executives close to the board.
After Selling High, Buying Low Bargain hunters helped lift the Dow 90.11 points, or 1.1 percent, to 8,552.96. The S.& P. 500 rose 1.4 percent and the Nasdaq climbed 1.8 percent.
